What is the general form of a polynomial f(x) of degree n?
What does it mean when three values a, b, and c lead to the same result of f(x)=-1, especially considering they are different integers?
Form the polynomial g(x) by defining it as f(x) + 1. What is the significance of g(x) in finding the roots of f(x)?
What can be derived about the polynomial g(x) knowing that it has at least three roots (a, b, c)?
Determine the degree of g(x) relative to the degree of f(x) and understand how this affects the number of roots g(x) can have.
How do the coefficients being integers influence the total number of integer roots that g(x) can have?
Summarize the maximum number of integer roots that f(x) can have, given the polynomial g(x) and its properties.

What kind of polynomial is f(x), and what constraints do the conditions f(a) = f(b) = f(c) = -1 impose on its structure?
How can we model the existence of the values a, b, c where f(a) = f(b) = f(c) = -1 in terms of factors of the polynomial?
What is the minimum degree of a polynomial that accommodates these three conditions where f(a) = -1, f(b) = -1, and f(c) = -1?
How many integer-valued roots can potentially exist if a polynomial is of degree n and also satisfies the above conditions?
Can there be other integer-valued roots apart from a, b, and c? If so, how are these additional roots related to the given conditions?
How does knowing the polynomial has integer coefficients influence the possible number and nature of its roots?
What is the maximum number of integer-valued roots possible under these conditions, and how do we calculate it?
How can the principle of polynomial interpolation help in determining an upper bound on the number of different integer roots the polynomial can have?

Consider the polynomial f(x) and acknowledge that it has integer coefficients and is of degree n.
Recognize and define what it means for the polynomial f(x) to have the same value, -1, at three different integer points a, b, and c.
Consider what kind of polynomial equation could be formed with roots at a, b, and c, and implications for the form of f(x).
Determine the remainder of the polynomial when divided by the polynomial (x-a)(x-b)(x-c), knowing that f(a) = f(b) = f(c) = -1.
Formulate the new polynomial g(x) = f(x) + 1, which has zeros at x = a, b, c.
Analyze the degree and leading coefficient of g(x) and understand its implications for the rest of the integer roots apart from a, b, and c.
Calculate or estimate the maximum number of integer roots that g(x), and hence f(x), can have, considering its degree and the properties of rational roots.
Sum up all possible integer roots, including a, b, and c, to determine the maximum possible number of integer-valued roots for f(x).
